Award.AwardTitle: Targeted Infusion Project Grant: Fostering Innovation and Excellence in Computing Systems: Establishing an Innovative Systems Laboratory

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Targeted Infusion Project entitled -Fostering Innovation and Excellence in Computing Systems: Establishing an Innovative Systems Laboratory - has the goal to foster innovation in undergraduate students in the Computer Science program. To foster innovation, this project uses a novel approach which systematically introduces innovation in a step-wise fashion in six courses, followed by the completion of a senior design project in the Innovative Systems Laboratory.

The objectives of the project are to introduce innovation in six fundamental computer science courses using top down and bottom up approaches; create a web service, cloud computing and mobile computing based infrastructure framework and the associated infrastructure components within this general framework; and use this general framework to develop innovative web services and cloud computing based computing systems projects. The anticipated outcomes of this project are an increase in the number of undergraduate students from groups underrepresented in computer science (African American, Hispanic, and women), who learn the skills to innovate and demonstrate that they can use the current technologies to create innovative computing systems. The approach is scalable and replicable. This project will provide detailed setup instructions, training guides, source code and documentation to other small Computer Science programs nationwide.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project helped introduce innovation into computer science education from the freshman level. Two approaches, a top-down and bottom-up approaches were used to introduce innovation in all of computer science courses. Through top-down approach, senior students mentored lowerclassman and encouraged them to participate in the innovative projects they are working on. Senior students made presentations about their projects in the junior, sophomore and freshman level courses. All the faculties were on board to introduce innovation into computer science education, by having students work on project ideas that were innovative from the very first course of computer science degree plan. Involvement in the mentoring process, research, and implementation of the innovative projects, helped some of our students to decide upon graduate school as opposed to corporate America after graduation.

A cloud computing based infrastructure was created on AWS and was made accessible to students, so they can implement and host their projects on the cloud. This made projects accessible, so students could work outside classroom or campus. The use of Amazon cloud and deployment of the latest technologies for their projects really helped students go beyond the simple software that is available on their computer to implement the project. It helped our student’s train and think innovatively for 21st-century organizations. For the implementation of their senior design projects, having to work on the cloud-based technology that is currently being used by the corporate America, our students are going into the industry with hands-on experience and innovative thinking. Previously our students were mostly being hired as sales support or customer support staff, we have noticed an increasing number of our students are being hired for the product development and innovation.

Despite a strong emphasis on affirmative actions, United States of America has a significantly low number of African American professors. The shortage is felt not at the HBCU's alone but across the nation. PI observed that majority of our students are interested in full-time industry jobs after graduation, less than 1% are interested to pursue graduate school. As part of the top-down approach of the project, senior design students presented their ideas to the junior, sophomore and freshman students. They had to explain their ideas in detail, and in order to explain in detail, they had to come in better prepared. And after the presentations, each senior design team took on some lowerclassman to work with them on the projects and mentored them. As part of this process, some of the students realized they liked mentoring and helping other students learn. Our students graduating college to attend graduate school has been increasing steadily since the project has begun. By continuing the approaches outlined in the project, we believe we will be able to encourage more students to complete graduate school and Ph.D. degree to enter academia. Our project targeted traditionally underrepresented students – African American, Hispanics, and females. 90% of the students participated in our project on innovative projects are from minority groups.

Our enrollment has been on the steady increase since Fall 2012. Our current enrollment is 90% higher than the semester our project execution began. Our project has made a strong contribution to the enrollment and retention. Computer Science I is the first programming course all computer science students take. Along with CS students, we also have students register from other majors because it is a university core course. All the students (computer science and other majors) were involved with the project activities via Computer Science I course, students were involved in innovative project development via working on small parts of the innovative projects, by listening to the senior students' presentations and by attending other project activities on campus. Some of the students in CS-I, whose majors were undecided or were non-stem majors, ended up selecting computer science as their major after the CS I course, hence the project did have a direct impact on the enrollment of students to CS major.

For the first time, our students participated in hackathons conducted internally and nationally. In collaboration with the ACM chapter on campus, one Hackathon, and one Problem Solving session were conducted in Fall 2016. The project helped send 4 students to Black Enterprise 2017 BE Smart Hackathon held in California. 10 students attended IBM BlueHack held in Atlanta. 32 of our students attended the IBM two-day trip held in Austin. All the students attended the Hackathons were prepared for the events and were confident due to their involvement in the project. A good number of our students were interviewed and currently doing the finish line interviews and expecting full time or internship offers early December 2017. Students vocalized to the PI and credited their success to their involvement on the innovative projects, interacting with their peers for the collaborations, and faculty guidance on innovative project implementation.
